subject: Async Reads Implementation
commitMessage:
Async Reads Implementation

In mainloop.cpp, the read() function iterates through all sensors
and attempts to read the value synchronously. Using the cache,
any call to read a sensor will return the cached value and create
an underlying request to io_uring to read the sensor again, for
the next time this sensor is read again (requests will be batched
to reduce kernel IO syscall overhead). More details in design
doc: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/44455

Preliminary data shows that latency has decreased considerably
(median faster by a factor of ~26x, 95% of io_uring reads are
faster than the fastest original read timing). Throughput has
also shown improvement, but its profiling was more arbitrary than
that of latency.

Signed-off-by: Jerry Zhu <jzhu379@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I693bfdfd649186471565fd4619c5988734555468

it looks like up above only handler and retriesRemaining are ever set to non default values, so you could just init the values to their defaults below instead of passing them through.
Changed constructor, only default value is now the return code rc, which I want to explicity set to 0.
what does CQE stand for? (I'm not familiar with io_uring)
Completion Queue Event. Basically a struct that gets filled out with info regarding the results of the submitted IO task.
Maybe I missed it, but is there a reason a unique_ptr is needed here?
I've always wrapped my dynamically allocated objects in smart pointers. Unsure if gBMC or modern C++ practices say differently.
Need to ensure that the commit messages are <72 chars for each line.
Done
Looks like your commit message regressed?

I believe our sensor value types are double https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-hwmon/blob/master/interface.hpp#L32

But double should be 64bit anyway so works out to be the same, but we may want to update this.

Or use SensorValueType from interface.hpp

EDIT: I think what's happening is, we read the values as int64_t from hwmon but we report out to D-Bus in "double" hence the cast with "value" variable in mainloop. Maybe Matt can comment, as I wasn't too involved / familiar with that transition.
Yep, I based the int64_t type from the existing hwmonio.hpp file, while returns int64_t in its read() function.
super minor nit: I think it'd be easier to read here (and other doxygen comments) if you indented with a space for every line in the same heading).
Done
nit: what does e stand for? entry? Prefer descriptive (but concise) name if possible, as e is usually reserved for errors
Changed from 'e'.
We may want to bring "ASYNC" read (with the #if) here - to avoid synchronous sensor read on a very slow sensor taking down the daemon if we choose to.
What should be the default return value if the first read is async? This function requires I return or throw something.
same as in the header: I'm not sure we need to dynamically make_unique since we know that it'll always be a char array of MAX_READ_SIZE
Done
Were you able to observe any error cases? We may want to quickly inject a sensor that emits errors to see if this is being handled correctly.
No. A Vim search on the journalctl logs yielded nothing io_uring error related.
For those not familiar with io_uring, it might be good to have a quick summary of what you're doing (queuing up a read on the hwmon fd)
Done
nit: I think for "simple" constructors like this where it's just initialization list, I prefer just putting it inline in the header.
Done
Just to be clear, you're -ing the -errno, so making it positive, so that for NEGATIVE_ERRNO_ON_FAIL, we return -errno (by -rc) right? (a bit of a mind twister)
Yeah, making the errno positive for easier processing above. And if there is an error, returning it back to -errno for error handling.
nit: I think for "simple" constructors like this where it's just initialization list, I prefer just putting it inline in the header.

I think this can just be std::array<char, MAX_READ_SIZE> then you don't have to deal with smart pointers with std::move and make_unique, etc.
